;

;澳大利亚人民拒绝了在提议在宪法中承认原住民时，老杰拉尔丁·霍加斯 (Geraldine Hogarth) 在金矿区的家中哭泣。

;

;“这对我们来说是悲伤的一天。悲伤如此之痛，就像一把刀插在你的心上，”库瓦拉·皮尼·贾尔卡塔拉 (Kuwarra Pini Tjalkatarra) 女士说道。

;

;霍加斯 (Hogarth) 一生都住在利奥诺拉 (Leonora)，并毕生致力于倡导人们的教育和福祉。社区儿童 - 并因其努力而被授予澳大利亚勋章。

;
    ;

;

;但现在她正在处理结果并想知道从这里到哪里。

;

;澳大利亚以压倒性多数投票反对奉行;原住民向议会发出声音;，就影响原住民的问题向政策和立法者提供建议。只有40%的澳大利亚人投了赞成票。首都领地是唯一投赞成票的管辖区。

;
;

;;相关：;;原住民社区以压倒性多数投票赞成澳大利亚向议会发出的声音;

;
;

;霍加斯说，这次公投的结果与 1967 年关于她的人民的第一次全国投票的结果有很大不同。

;

;那次公投改变了宪法中提及原住民和托雷斯海峡岛民的方式，消除了选举的障碍。将原住民纳入人口普查，并赋予联邦政府制定有关原住民和托雷斯海峡岛民的特别法律的权力。

;

    ;“1967 年公投时我大约八九岁，我记得我的家人都在谈论这件事，现在对我来说这是非常悲伤的一天。我一直在哭——我知道我再也看不到另一次公投了。”她说。

    ;

    ;曾祖母在她那个时代见过太多的原住民咨询机构来来去去，她认为也许有一个机构被奉为神圣不可侵犯的。宪法将提供保护和稳定。

    ;

    ;“他们只是不断地砍伐和改变。没有什么是具体的。你总是认为它们会留下来，但那从未发生过，而且会有一个好的，然后六个月后它就消失了。”

    ;

    ;就像她家乡西部州社区的许多人一样在澳大利亚，她在投票结束前几小时发现公投被否决。

    ;

    ;许多其他原住民也在努力应对结果，尚未准备好公开表达他们的感受。一份得到许多社区领袖和组织支持的沉默声明得到了广泛传播，这呼应了支持议会发言的原住民所感受到的悲伤和拒绝。

    ; ;

    ;虽然有原住民支持，但也有一些人从未在非- 具有约束力的咨询机构，权力很小。

    ;

    ;在梅尔岛托雷斯海峡群岛或墨累岛，妇女和教育倡导者梅洛拉·诺亚 (Melora Noah) 不同意设立咨询机构的想法，质疑其运作方式和它如何能够充分代表像她这样的多元化社区。;

    ;尽管她自己投票反对该提案，但她对公投如此彻底地失败感到震惊：“我没想到它会这样下去，我以为至少有几个州会支持它……作为一名原住民，这仍然令人失望。”诺亚说。

    ;

    ;她不认为这次投票是针对原住民的，而是将其称为失败的结果。沟通、竞选和滴答作响的时钟。 “人们不理解，他们不知道自己投票的是什么，为时已晚，而且没有明确说明。这就像当你去买一台洗衣机时，你想知道你付的钱是什么。”她说。

    ;

    ;“澳大利亚投了反对票，这让我大开眼界，但这与责备。竞选活动没有说明他们到底投票的是什么。”

    ;
    ;

    ;;相关：;;公投的五点见解：自由党赢得了战斗，但输掉了战争战争;

    ;
    ;

    ;特雷西·韦斯特曼（Tracy Westerman）博士是一位领先的原住民心理学家，她在工作中倡导基于创伤和基于证据的自杀预防，她说需要发出声音。

    ;

    ;“我们的儿童自杀率是非原住民儿童自杀率的六倍。我们继续资助无效的主流计划，这些计划对降低风险没有任何影响，”韦斯特曼说。

    ;

    ;“这就是为什么我们需要声音，如果我们有偏远的土著社区说这些计划对我们有用，我们就会拥有有效的资金。

    ;

    ;“现在，我们只需要继续做草根游说者，继续说、做我们一直在做的事情。黑人激进主义永远是一场持久战。可悲的是，我们实际上要求尽可能最低的要求，只是为了得到考虑，”韦斯特曼说。

    ;

    ;“只需​​要一点时间、反思和治愈。今天有很多痛苦，这是完全可以理解的，因为原住民，我们只是敞开心扉，就像我们在全国道歉中所做的那样。”

    ;

    ;在利奥诺拉中，霍加斯说她会哭泣并坐下来失去家园和悲伤——这种事情太常见了，葬礼和过早死亡在整个社区蔓延。

    ;

    ;“在西澳大利亚州、金矿区和其他地方，与我们的 Wongi 一起， ” 。他们试图摆脱我们，但我们站起来了。”

    ; Mon, 16 Oct 2023 13:52:02 +0800 X fined $610,500 in Australia first for failing to crack down on child sexual abuse materialhttps://www.theguardian.com/technology/2023/oct/16/x-fined-610500-in-australia-first-for-failing-to-crack-down-on-child-sexual-abuse-material

    ;;X Twitter 徽标
    ;

    ;X，该公司的前身为 Twitter，已成为第一家上线的公司根据澳大利亚在线安全法案，该平台将因未能满足基本在线安全预期而被处以 610,500 美元的罚款。

    ;

    ;X 有 28 天的时间支付由电子安全专员 Julie Inman 发出的罚款格兰特，或对专员 X 在打击平台上儿童性虐待内容的工作中忽视的问题做出答复。

    ;

    ;法律声明已发布 ;X、Google、TikTok、Twitch 和继去年向 Apple、Meta、Microsoft、Snap 和 Omegle 发送第一轮通知后，二月份出现了 Discord。

    ;

    ;在周一发布的一份关于科技公司对通知的回应的报告中，专员发现许多最大的服务机构未能充分检测、删除和防止虐待儿童的材料。

    ;

    ;“坦率地说，我对提取精确和准确的信息有多么困难感到惊讶，坦率地说，令人惊讶的是，一些本应拥有更复杂和成熟的系统和资源的公司似乎不愿意或无法提供其他公司已提供的信息，”英曼·格兰特告诉澳大利亚卫报。 “或者就 Twitter 而言，将所有内容完全留空，以混淆[不提供]不准确的信息。”

    ;
    ;

    ;;相关：;;欧盟在 Twitter 发现后警告埃隆·马斯克虚假信息率最高;

    ;
    ;

    ;专员还发现 X 和 Google 没有遵守通知，Google 对一些具体问题给出了笼统的答复，而对一些问题则给出了笼统的答复。 X 完全没有得到答复。

    ;

    ;Google 已收到正式警告，而 X 则收到侵权通知。

    ;

    ;Google 澳大利亚公共政策和政府事务总监 Lucinda Longcroft 表示在一份声明中，保护儿童是 Google 所做的最重要的工作，该公司已投入巨资开展工作，以阻止儿童性虐待材料的传播。

    ;

    ;“我们仍然致力于这些努力，并进行建设性的合作，与电子安全专员、政府和行业真诚地合作，实现让澳大利亚人上网更安全的共同目标。”

    ;

    ;当英曼·格兰特 (Inman Grant) 今年早些时候发布通知时，她指出 X 的所有者埃隆·马斯克 (Elon Musk) 曾表示儿童安全是他对该平台的首要任务，但报告发现，在马斯克收购该公司并裁员 80% 后的三个月内，虐待儿童材料的自动检测率从 90% 下降到 75%

    ;

    ;该公司告诉电子安全专员，自那以后它已经有所改善，但没有提供任何细节来证实这一说法。

    ;

    ;虽然英曼没有标记马斯克兑现了他的承诺，但格兰特表示，这是一件“相当大的事情”，她甚至无法从该公司得到关于该公司还有多少信任和安全员工的答案。

    ;

    ;这些公司最初有 35 天的时间做出回应通知，但多次延期导致该过程耗时七个月。

    ;

    ;“我们知道这很困难，而且对于这些公司来说，实际上说，‘好吧......我们已经说过这是我们的首要任务，但实际上，我们什么也没做。”英曼·格兰特说。

    ;

    ;“他们已经签署了这些自愿原则，包括五只眼、打击儿童性行为的自愿原则滥用……我们通过我们质疑的所有 13 家公司发现，没有一家公司遵守这些原则。”

    ;

    ;Inman Grant 表示，她发现 TikTok 最重要的是更加透明

    ;

    ;如果 X 在澳大利亚不再有业务，未能对侵权通知做出回应，也没有遵守提供所要求的信息，该办公室可以将 X 告上联邦法院，自今年 3 月起，该公司每天可被处以最高 78 万美元的罚款。

    ;

    ;“这也不意味着我们就完了。我们有定期通知的权力，”英曼·格兰特说。 “我们希望向......我们拥有的所有手段施加压力，以确保他们改善和提高安全标准。”

    ;

    ;澳大利亚卫报寻求 X 的回应，并收到了来自新闻电子邮件地址的标准自动回复。

    ;气候运动组织的研究;可能;表示，收入与拥有大型SUV之间存在很强的相关性，这意味着有充分的理由支持根据尺寸对车辆排放进行“污染者支付”税。

    ;

    ;英格兰车辆拥有量数据显示，收入最高 20% 的家庭拥有车辆的可能性高出 81%与其他 80% 的车主相比，排放量较高的汽车。

    ;

    ;收入最高的 20% 群体每年驾驶的里程是收入最低的五分之一群体的三倍。

    ;

    ;研究发现，最富有的人的驾驶习惯对气候的破坏比“最贫穷的人”更严重。

    ;

    ;伦敦肯辛顿区和切尔西区的汽车保有量数据发现，拥有一辆 SUV 与生活在较富裕的地区，对于像路虎卫士这样的超重型、高排放汽车来说更是如此。该行政区最富裕地区近四分之一的汽车属于这一类，而较贫困地区这一比例为 5%。

    ;

    ;这项研究是在人们越来越担心汽车对环境、健康和安全影响的背景下进行的。 SUV 越来越受欢迎，通常是重量超过两吨的大型四轮驱动车辆。

    ;

    ;虽然 SUV 的定义可能有所不同，但在英国销售的汽车中属于 SUV 的比例近年来，横幅从大约五分之一上升到近三分之一。

    ;

    ;虽然它们被宣传为覆盖崎岖地面或牵引重物的车辆，但;之前的研究;表明，在英国购买的新 SUV 中，有四分之三的注册人是居住在城市地区的人。

    ; <研究计算出，SUV 销量上升的影响，以及它们往往比以前购买的传统车型明显重的事实，意味着 2023 年购买的传统发动机汽车的平均碳排放量高​​于 2013 年的同类汽车。< /p>;

    ;该报告呼吁区分根据温室气体排放对司机收费，而不是根据氮氧化物 (NOx) 等对公共健康有直接影响的排放收费。

    ;

    ;

    ;相反，报告认为，高温室排放通常是富人购买大型SUV的产物——其价格表明他们可以买得起电动汽车。

    ;

    ;作者表示，基于碳排放的停车和道路使用者收费也有社会正义的理由。

    ;

    ;伦敦南部的兰贝斯向最重、最高排放车辆的车主收取的年度停车许可证费用是最小汽车的四倍多。肯辛顿和切尔西的类似计划差异高达 10 倍。

    ;

    ;其他议会也应该效仿，Possible 表示：“切尔西的拖拉机已经对未来发起了攻击，如果我们不反抗的话快速回来，我们都会发现自己在它的车轮下。”

    ;

    ;SUV 在其他一些国家甚至更加流行，约占美国总销量的一半。今年，总部位于巴黎的国际能源机构;表示，在全球;，SUV 产生的排放量相当于英国和德国全国排放总量的总和。

    ;

    ;在美国，人们单独关注对行人和车辆的安全影响。 SUV，尤其是超大型“卡车”上的骑自行车者。

    ;

    ; Mon, 16 Oct 2023 13:22:01 +0800 Sniffer dogs deployed to seek out bedbugs in UK hotels and homeshttps://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2023/oct/16/sniffer-dogs-deployed-to-seek-out-bedbugs-in-uk-hotels-and-homes
    ;;2023-10-16T05:00:34Z;
    ;
    ;;臭虫嗅探犬
    ;

    ;酒店和房主正在召唤经过特殊训练的狗来嗅出臭虫由于担心英国的虫害不断增加，臭虫可能潜伏在卧室的裂缝和缝隙中。

    ;

    ;在新冠病毒危机期间，随着酒店关闭和旅行停滞，臭虫的传播有所下降，但自世界重新开放后，休眠人口已经开始反弹，即使尚未恢复到大流行之前达到的水平。

    ;

    ;虽然人口数量的增加引发了一波反感浪潮 — — 偶尔还会给受影响的人带来创伤 — — 但事实证明，这只是一个小问题-英国专业公司的蓬勃发展，这些公司部署训练有素的嗅探犬来检测从私人住宅到五星级酒店等各处的感染。

    ;

    ;西米德兰兹郡索利哈尔 K9 检测服务公司的首席执行官加里·杰克曼 (Gary Jakeman) 表示，两只训练有素的史宾格犬米洛和科比，它们的服务越来越受到酒店业主和怀疑虫子在其场所立足的个人的追捧。

    ;
    ;

    ;;相关：;;别介意法国的联系。臭虫已经在英国的家中生存，我们必须与它们共存 |詹姆斯·洛根;

    ;
    ;

    ;“我们的兴趣越来越浓厚。自 6 月份以来，我们的标注数量可能增加了 25%，”Jakeman 说道。 “这些狗很准确。训练有素的鼻子很难逃脱任何东西。”

    ;

    ;训练一只新狗嗅出臭虫可能需要一年到 18 个月的时间。这个过程类似于训练狗闻毒品、爆炸物和金钱的方法。就臭虫而言，狗会检测到昆虫释放的信息素，以帮助它们聚集在一起。

    ;

    ;“浓度非常高时，你自己就能闻到，”该床的主任理查德·内勒博士说臭虫基金会提供有关昆虫的信息，并与犬类培训学校合作，对狗进行臭虫检测认证。 “它们会产生一种非常刺鼻的、可识别的气味。”

    ;

    ;这些昆虫很少会离开它们进食的地方超过一米，因此经常在床头附近被发现，但可能需要几个小时才能找到它们只携带手电筒和良好的视力。杰克曼说，经过训练的狗可以在几分钟内找到它们，或者排除它们。

    ;

    ;臭虫最常见的症状是被叮咬，对它们有反应的人会肿胀并发痒。但床单上的臭虫粪便或血迹也是感染的其他迹象。如果不拆开床并检查所有接缝和凹处，可能就找不到昆虫本身。 “我们以前在电视遥控器和插头插座中发现过它们，”杰克曼说。

    ;

    ;虽然对身体无害，但感染可能会造成创伤。 “这对心理健康的影响可能是毁灭性的，”内勒说。

    ;

    ;“它使人孤立。他们感到羞耻，因为人们错误地将他们与恶劣的生活条件联系起来。人们不会去看朋友，也不希望朋友来找他们。人们因为开着灯睡觉而变得睡眠不足。它可以产生持久的影响：在虫子消失很久之后，人们仍能感觉到有东西在皮肤上爬行。”

    ;

    ;布莱恩·莱斯 (Brian Leith) 在南拉纳克郡经营 BDL 犬类服务公司，他与一只史宾格犬本吉 (Benji) 一起工作。西班牙猎犬混合。如果酒店收到有关臭虫的投诉，两人将检查有问题的房间和附近的六间房间。 “这与肮脏的房子根本无关，”他说。 “我住过的五星级酒店都有它们。”

    ;
    ;

    ;;相关：;;萨迪克·汗表示，伦敦交通中的臭虫是“真正令人担忧的来源”;

    ;
    ;

    ;New Zealand could be stuck in political limbo for weeks as the newly elected National party waits to see if it can govern solely with its preferred coalition partner, Act, or whether the final vote tally will force it to work with populist party New Zealand First.

    ;

    ;;Saturday night's election; brutally ousted the governing Labour party, with preliminary results giving the centre-right National party 50 seats, and its traditional coalition party Act, 11 - just enough to reach the 61 seats needed to govern.

    ;

    ;But two significant developments over the next six weeks could destabilise their position.

    ;
    ;

    ;;Related: ;;New Zealand Labour shed votes to the right but also the left – the price of a progressive policy bonfire;

    ;
    ;

    ;Roughly 570,000 “special votes” – those cast from overseas, or outside a voter's electorate – are still being counted, with the final results due on 3 November.

    ;

    ;Should those votes, which tend to favour the left, chip down National or Act's numbers, it would force the pair to cut a deal with NZ First leader Winston ;Peters; – a maverick politician who could slam the breaks on some of National and Act's core policies.

    ;

    ;A strong showing for Te Pāti Māori could also influence the shape of the future government. The party won more electorate seats its party vote projected and under New Zealand's mixed member proportional system, that could increase the size of the parliament – meaning National-Act will need to secure more seats to govern.

    ;

    ;On Monday morning, incoming prime minister, National's ;Christopher Luxon;, confirmed to ;RNZ; he would talk with NZ First before the special votes were counted, but declined to discuss what negotiations, if any, could look like.

    ;

    ;“We're going to work with each individual party, we're going to do that in a way that respects them and is done privately,” Luxon said.

    ;

    ;If it comes to a choice, National will need to decide if it wants to stick with a fragile majority, or partner with a party that is sure to cause it headaches.

    ;

    ;“Trying to govern with a one seat majority is going to be very, very difficult,” says Prof Andrew Geddis, an expert in electoral law from the University of Otago.

    ;
    ;

    ;;Related: ;;Some of Jacinda Ardern's legacy in New Zealand is safe. A lot of it isn't | Henry Cooke;

    ;
    ;

    ;“It's one MP being outed for something terrible and having to leave parliament away from being a hung parliament.”

    ;

    ;The last two elections have resulted in two seats flipping from National to Labour, Geddis said.

    ;

    ;“Unless the special votes are very different to what they have been in the past, Luxon is not going to have enough seats to govern…at the moment Luxon has to figure that he will need New Zealand First.”

    ;

    ;In past elections where ;Peters has been the kingmaker;, he has demanded that his party be around the cabinet table, taking part in all the decisions and in some instances, holding off the other support partner, Geddis said.

    ;

    ;“Whether Act will put up with that is another question,” he said.

    ; ;

    ;New Zealanders are unlikely to see how negotiations are progressing until those special votes are revealed, Geddis said.

    ;

    ;“National and Act will be talking between each other about how they are going to handle Peters, but Peters has been around for a long time and he has got a particular set of demands as to how he is treated personally as well as how his party is dealt with,” Geddis said. “If he doesn't get that, it will be interesting to see if he is prepared to deal at all.”

    ;

    ;Peters has slammed a number of National and Act's policy promises as being unaffordable and at risk of driving inflation – in particular National's plan to allow some foreign buyers back into the housing market, National's tax cuts and both National and Act's desire to slash funds and jobs from public services. Peters does not want to see superannuation age raised from 65 to 67, nor agricultural emissions priced in any form – both on National's agenda.

    ;Daniel Noboa, the heir to a banana fortune who pledges a hard line on rocketing violent crime, employment for the young and foreign investment, will become Ecuador's youngest ever president at 35 after winning by a margin of around five points over his rival, the leftist lawyer Luisa González.

    ;

    ;With 90% of votes counted on Sunday night in Ecuador, Noboa had 52.29% of the vote against 47.71% for González, according to ;Ecuador's electoral council.;

    ;

    ;“Today we have made history,” said Noboa in a ;message; on X, formerly known as Twitter. “Ecuadorian families chose the new Ecuador, they chose a country with security and employment.”

    ;

    ;He added that electoral promises would not just remain in the campaign and corruption would be punished.

    ;
    ;

    ;;Related: ;;'People are dying in the street': Ecuador election overshadowed by violent crime;

    ;
    ;

    ;This election was held against a backdrop of a spike in ;violent crime fuelled by drug trafficking;, which has turned the country into one of the most violent in the region with the fourth-highest homicide rate – higher even than Mexico.

    ;

    ;Noboa, the millennial son of Ecuador's richest man and five-time presidential candidate Álvaro Noboa, was the surprise entry into the second round in August. His calm and unconfrontational style made him popular, particularly with voters aged between 18 and 29 who make up a third of the electorate.

    ;

    ;The Harvard Kennedy School graduate focused his campaign on creating jobs and the economy, recommending tax exemptions and incentives for new businesses as well as pledging to attract more foreign investment.

    ;
    ;

    ;;Related: ;;'We should treat it as a war': Ecuador's descent into drug gang violence;

    ;
    ;

    ;On crime, Noboa proposed putting the most violent criminals on ships off Ecuador's Pacific coast. He also suggested boosting the military presence on the borders and coast, both of which are trafficking points for cocaine.

    ;

    ;Arianna Tanca, an Ecuadorian political analyst, said the stakes were high and urged the former congressman to think about the “future of the country and not preserving his square metre of power”.

    ;

    ;Noboa is due to be sworn in on 25 November but will only govern for 17 months until 2025 – completing the term of outgoing president, Guillermo Lasso, who dissolved congress in May during an impeachment trial and called snap presidential and legislative elections.

    ;

    ;“It's a short time but it is time that is precious and can be used for good so let's see if the politicians are up to the bar,” said Tanca.

    ;

    ;“Ecuadoreans need peace, we can't stand the violence any more, this war,” said Carla Espinoza, voting in Quito on Sunday.

    ;

    ;The presidential campaign has been marked by unprecedented violence, including the assassination in broad daylight of ;anti-corruption candidate Fernando Villavicencio; as he left a campaign event in August. This month, ;seven Colombian suspects in the assassination were themselves murdered; in prison.

    ; ;

    ;Ecuador's Pacific ports are targeted by drug traffickers smuggling cocaine, most commonly in shipping containers holding bananas, the country's top export. About 80% of cocaine smuggled from Ecuador was bound for Europe, the country's interior minister Juan Zapata told the Guardian, where a kilo of cocaine fetched a street price of around $50,000 – twice as much as in the US.

    ;Zapata said Ecuador, positioned between Colombia and Peru, the world's main cocaine producing countries, needed international help to tackle a “common transnational enemy”. Homicide rates have risen fivefold since 2019, according to the ;Ecuadorean Observatory on Organised Crime;, due to violence between local gangs allied with Mexican drug cartels, Colombian guerrilla groups and Balkan traffickers.

    ;

    ;The president-elect will not have a parliamentary majority and could struggle to find consensus to push through legislation among Ecuador's fractious political class.

    ;

    ;“There is so much to do,” said Zapata. “I hope that the new congress dedicates itself to [dealing with the security situation] unlike the previous one that wasted so much time and hurt the country.”

    ;;2023-10-16T01:19:42Z;

    ;;Iranian film director Dariush Mehrjui and his wife Vahideh Mohammadifar.
    ;

    ;One of Iran's most prominent film-makers, Dariush Mehrjui, was stabbed to death on Saturday evening alongside his wife at their home near Tehran, authorities have said.

    ;

    ;A provincial chief justice said Mehrjui and his wife, Vahideh Mohammadifar, “were killed by multiple stab wounds to the neck”, according to the judiciary's Mizan online website.

    ;

    ;According to Hossein Fazeli-Harikandi, chief justice of Alborz province near Tehran, Mehrjui sent a text message to his daughter, Mona, at about 9pm local time inviting her for dinner at their home in Karaj, west of Tehran. But upon her arrival an hour and a half later, she found the bodies of her dead parents with fatal wounds to their necks.

    ;

    ;Later in the day, police said “no signs of forced entry can be seen at the crime scene”, adding that “no damage has been done to the doors” of their home. However, they said “traces have been found” at the scene they believe to be “related to the murderer”.

    ;

    ;On Sunday, the Etemad newspaper featured an interview with the film-maker's wife saying she had been threatened and that their home had been burgled.

    ;

    ;“The investigation revealed that no complaints had been filed regarding the illegal entry into the Mehrjui's family villa and the theft of their belongings”, said Fazeli-Harikandi.

    ;

    ;In a statement, Iran's minister of culture, Mohammad-Mehdi Esmaili, hailed Mehrjui as “one of the pioneers of Iranian cinema” and “the creator of eternal works”.

    ;

    ;Born in 1939 in Tehran, Mehrjui studied philosophy in the United States before his return to Iran where he launched a literary magazine and released his first film in 1967, Diamond 33, a parody of the James Bond series.

    ;

    ;The 83-year-old was indelibly associated with the Iranian new wave of cinema, with his 1969 film The Cow one of the movement's first pictures. He then directed a string of well-regarded films including Mr Gullible and The Cycle before leaving Iran in the wake of the 1979 Islamic revolution.

    ;

    ;Between 1980 and 1985, he lived in France where he worked on the documentary Journey to the Land of Rimbaud. On returning to Iran, he received at the box office success with The Tenants in 1987.

    ;

    ;In 1990, he directed Hamoun, a dark comedy showing 24 hours in the life of an intellectual tormented by divorce and psychological anxieties in an Iran overwhelmed by the technology companies Sony and Toshiba.

    ;

    ;Throughout the 1990s, Mehrjui also depicted the lives of women in Sara, Pari and Leila, a melodrama about an infertile woman who encourages her husband to marry a second woman.

    ;

    ;In interviews with the Iranian media, Mehrjui said he was “greatly influenced” by Swedish film-maker Ingmar Bergman and Italian Michelangelo Antonioni.

    ;

    ;“I don't make directly political films to promote a particular ideology or point of view. But everything is political,” he once said.

    ;

    ;To Mehrjui, cinema was like “poetry, which cannot take sides with anyone” and he remained adamant that “art must not become a propaganda tool”.

    ;

    ;In addition to his cinema career, he translated works by the French playwright Eugene Ionesco and the German Marxist philosopher Herbert Marcuse into Persian.

    ;A long-lost prop from the original 1977 ;Star Wars; film has sold in an auction for a record-breaking US$3.135m.

    ;The prop, a 20-inch model of an X-Wing starfighter that was used in the climactic battle sequence of Star Wars: Episode IV – A New Hope, had been considered missing for decades before it was discovered in a cardboard box in the garage of the Oscar-nominated model-maker Greg Jein.     ;;Related: ;;Oh dear, George Lucas! Why the Star Wars universe is going from bad to worse ;

    ;

    ;The auction also included a vast array of other film artefacts from Jein's collection, including an original Stormtrooper costume from A New Hope, an astronaut suit from 2001: A Space Odyssey and miniatures from Battlestar Galactica.

    ;“The worldwide response to the Greg Jein collections been outstanding,” Maddalena's statement continued. “A true testament to Greg and all he accomplished as visual effects artist and collector.”

    ;

    ;Built by George Lucas's visual effects company Industrial Light & Magic, the model was used in the final battle of A New Hope, including the famous trench run.     ;

    ;The model stood in for the X-Wings known as Red Leader, Red Two and Red Five, the latter flown by Luke Skywalker.

    ;

    ;“This model has not been displayed or modified since it left ILM,” a visual effects historian, Gene Kozicki, told ;the Hollywood Reporter;;, ;describing the prop as a “white whale”.

    ;

    ;The historian discovered the model in Jein's garage while working with several industry colleagues to help Jein's family organise his collection.     ;

    ;Kozicki said it was unknown how the X-Wing had become part of Jein's collection, though he speculated Jein may have obtained it while working on Steven Spielberg's 1977 film Close Encounters of the Third Kind, which shared a significant portion of its visual effects team with the original Star Wars.

An exit poll in ;Slovakia's election earlier this month; appeared to show a victory for a progressive coalition, only for the actual results to be strikingly different.

    ;

    ;“[The] president can give PiS first chance to form government, delaying opposition,” said Stanley Bill, professor of Polish studies at Cambridge University, ;writing on X;, formerly Twitter. “Crucial to wait for official results (by Tuesday) - small differences could somewhat alter the picture.”

    ;

    ;However, the mood at the Civic Coalition HQ was jubilant. “The next 40 hours, 60 hours will show how we build this coalition. But for us it's obvious that the [government] coalition will be us, the Third Way and the left,” said Borys Budka, head of the Civic Coalition parliamentary faction.

    ;

    ;Budka also said an opposition win would mark the return of Poland to friendly relations with the EU and an end to the threat of a “Polexit”.

    ;

    ;Barbara Nowacka, a Civic Coalition MP who has been fiercely critical of the PiS crackdown on abortion rights, said it was clear the opposition had won, and said it was an important day for Polish women.

    ;

    ;“Young women won't be afraid to get pregnant, young women won't be afraid to go to the doctor,” she said.

    ; ;

    ;Jarosław Kaczyński, 74, the PiS chair, said his party's result was a big success, but admitted “we don't know” whether the party had a path to government.

    ;

    ;“Days of fight and tension await us,” he told supporters just after the exit poll was released. If PiS is indeed the biggest party, it has the right to have the first attempt at forming a coalition.

    ;

    ;“Whether we are in power or in the opposition, we will continue implementing our project and will not allow Poland to be betrayed,” he said.

    ;

    ;In a bitterly divisive campaign over recent months, both sides have painted the vote as being of decisive importance for the future of Poland. Tusk had described the election as “the last chance” to stop PiS from doing irreparable damage to Polish democracy.

    ;

    ;PiS ran a campaign from the populist playbook, claiming it was the only party that can protect Poland from an “invasion” of refugees. The campaign has also focused on the figure of Tusk, 66, relentlessly attacking the challenger as a foreign stooge.

    ;

    ;The election was on course for a turnout of over 72%, the highest since the fall of communism. As the polls closed there were queues remaining outside many polling stations. Authorities said anyone who was queueing before the official end of voting would be able to vote.

    ;

    ;Earlier in the day, at one polling station in Wola district, opposition voters expressed confidence at the chances for an opposition victory.

    ;

    ;“I saw a lot of young people, more than four or eight years ago, which makes me optimistic,” said Pawel, 46, who had voted for Tusk's Civic Coalition. At the same polling station Maciej, 78, said the stereotype that older people support PiS was not true. “There are plenty of us who know how to think,” he said, tapping his forehead.

    ;

    ;Across town in the Gocław district, 77-year-old Grażyna said she voted for PiS because she believed they are the “fairest” of all the parties. “I hope they will be able to continue changing Poland for the better,” she said, after queueing for 20 minutes to vote.

    ;

    ;There were also long queues at Polish consulates abroad, with more than 600,000 Poles living outside the country registering to vote. On social media, people shared photographs and videos of long queues in various cities: one person ;said; they had waited three hours to vote in Palermo without getting to the front of the queue.

    ;

    ;Alongside the election, the government held a referendum, which asked four leading questions, including two on migration. One asked if people agree with “the admission of thousands of illegal immigrants from the Middle East and Africa”.

    ;

    ;The referendum was seen as a way to boost turnout among the PiS support base, as well as a way to circumvent electoral funding restrictions for the government. The opposition told its supporters to request only an election ballot and decline to take part in the referendum, which requires a 50% turnout to be valid.

    ;

    ;With so much at stake in the vote, there have been some concerns of possible foul play. Tens of thousands of Polish volunteers signed up to monitor the vote at polling stations.

    ;

    ;There are also concerns about potential attempts to discredit the results or interfere in the process in the event of a PiS defeat. Electoral results are ratified by the Chamber of Extraordinary Control and Public Affairs, added to the supreme court by the PiS government.

    ;

    ;Budka, however, said he believed the time for PiS was over. “Even if they try any tricks it wouldn't be something which changed the result,” he claimed.
